Award.AwardTitle: A Low-power, Quick-install Polar Observation System ('AMIGOS-II') for Monitoring Climate-ice-ocean Interactions
Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigators propose to build and test a multi-sensor, automated measurement station for monitoring Arctic and Antarctic ice-ocean environments. The system, based on a previously successful design, will incorporate weather and climate sensors, camera, snow and firn sensors, instruments to measure ice motion, ice and ocean thermal profilers, hydrophone, and salinity sensors. This new system will have two-way communications for real-time data delivery and is designed for rapid deployment by a small field group.

AMIGOS-II will be capable of providing real time information on geophysical processes such as weather, snowmelt, ice motion and strain, fractures and melt ponds, firn thermal profiling, and ocean conditions from multiple levels every few hours for 2-4 years. Project personnel will conduct a field test of the new system at a location with a deep ice-covered lake. Development of AMIGOS-II is motivated by recent calls by the U.S. Antarctic Program Blue-Ribbon Panel to increase Antarctic logistical effectiveness, which cites a need for greater efficiency in logistical operations. Installation of autonomous stations with reduced logistical requirements advances this goal.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The grant from NSF provided support for the development of a new research instrument intended to gather data in some of the most unexplored areas on our planet: the areas beneath floating ice in Antarctica and the Arcitc. The new instrument builds upon the success of 10 existing stations deployed in Antarctica that have been recording weather, ice movement, snow temperatures and snowfall rates, and melting on the southern continent. The stations also provide support for flight planning by pilots to remote sites, and observations of seals and penguins in coastal areas. A key feature of the stations is the ability to send data back on a daily basis through a satellite phone system (Iridium), and to receive new instructions on how to acquire data or prepare for polar winter.

We call the stations Automated Meteorology - Ice - Geophysics - Ocean Systems (AMIGOS). The new augmented station developed here is called AMIGOS-II.

The new grant supports integrating several new sensors to the proven multi-sensor station, and in particular a new fiber-optic-based sensor for providing a complete profile of ice and ocean temperature for up to a kilometer (0.6 miles) below the surface of a floating ice plate. This sensor, and several more standard sensors, will allow us to determine if warm or cold water enters the areas beneath the Antarctic ice sheet, how fast the water is moving, whether it is salty or slightly fresh water (from melting of ice) and how fast the base of the floating ice is melting or freezing. 

The sensor was developed and built in the first year of the grant, and in an extension period (no additional cost) the sensor system was tested on a frozen lake in Colorado. The system is now proven, and new copies of the station can be proposed for Antarctic field work in the future.
